segments.text: At the end of the outer circle of houses, at the beginning of the path that led to the sea, stood a house with red shutters, immersed in a large and magnificent garden, shaded at its center by a great chinaberry tree, with all its walls painted pink.
Thus it was given its name, the Pink House, written in round and beautiful letters on a sign placed beneath the street lamp.
That was also its address, no street, no number, only the Pink House, Ashkelon.
And the letters knew how to arrive, and so did the people.
This house, with its pink walls and red shutters, with its name that was also its address, was my home throughout all the days of my childhood and youth.
Since then I have passed through countless places and had many addresses like everyone else.
I crossed continents and seas and made myself other homes, but all of me and all that I will remain until my dying day is the girl from the pink house.
It is everything I am and everything I grew to be when it was taken from me and I was left without a home.

This magical house, whose walls were hung with the paintings of Yosef, my father, and the flea market collections of Lucy, my mother, a house interwoven with much of our history, a house that hosted the great leaders of the nation and the great figures of the Bohemian world.
a house where wonderful songs were written and are still sung by everyone to this very day.
This house one day lost its name and its color and turned into a jumble of houses for strangers.
Only on one faded wall does a trace of its pea.
All of its pinkness did not prevent the tragedies that befell me there.
In that house, I lost my mother before I had even turned 16.
A little more than two years later, I lost it too.
There began a chapter of my life, parts of which I chose to repress for years when repression became one of the most developed mechanisms within me.
And then one day, the dam simply burst, letting all the memories, both the beautiful and the less so, flow outward.
They meet me now when I am reconciled, knowing I was blessed.

My story is of that girl who grew up in freedom and great happiness, smiling in the pink house on the way to the sea with a pair of unique and somewhat bohemian parents, in a home that was a guest house, but above all was my home.

The story begins with the great fracture of my life, my mother's death, and continues with the sharp passage from an enchanted childhood in a pink wonderland to a sorrowful youth marked by loneliness and premature adulthood.
My story passes through First Love, Army Service, and Leora Finehiller.
